intro: Valeriana nevadensis, commonly known as the Sierra Valley valerian, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Caprifoliaceae family and is characterized by its aromatic, herbaceous stems and clusters of small, white to pinkish flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and streambanks. It has finely divided, lance-shaped leaves and produces small, capsule-like fruits. Valeriana nevadensis is valued for its ecological role in supporting pollinators and its historical use in traditional medicine.
